key_title: Key to the genera of Cyperaceae

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Monocotyledons

source.author: Wilson, K.L.
source.title: Cyperaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: Modified from: Wilson, K.L. (1994). Cyperaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Spikelets with several to many flowers producing nuts, usually only 1 to 2 lowest glumes empty
Spikelets or pseudospikelets with 1 to 2 flowers producing nuts, usually several to many empty glumes at the base of the spikelet or pseudospikelet
Culms noded and leafy; hypogynous bristles or scales present; robust perennials
Culms nodeless, leaves all basal (except occasionally in weak, branched, aquatic Isolepis species); hypogynous bristles or scales present or absent
Spikelets 1–2.5 cm long; inflorescence branches not scabrous; hypogynous bristles shorter than or equalling nut
Spikelets less than 1 cm long; inflorescence branches scabrous; hypogynous bristles much longer than nut
Style-base enlarged and persistent on nut; inflorescence not subtended by leafy bracts; leaves reduced to sheaths, glabrous; hypogynous bristles usually present
Style-base enlarged or not, but not persistent on nut
Hypogynous bristles present
Hypogynous bristles absent

Nuts smooth, epidermal cells isodiametric to narrowly oblong; rhizome elongate, creeping or ascending; glumes entire or minutely notched, or emarginate to bifid at the apex; hypogynous bristles present; culms solitary or a few-fascicled, nodeless above the base; perennial

Nuts smooth or transversely rugulose to sharply ridged, epidermal cells narrowly oblong to linear; rhizome very short and hidden among the culm-bases, or shortly lying, or elongate and creeping; glumes entire at the apex; hypogynous bristles present or absent; culms tufted or solitary, nodeless or 1(–3)-noded above the base; annual or perennial
Style based enlarged
Style based not enlarged
Style 2- fid
Style 3-fid
Glumes distichously arranged in spikelet
Glumes spirally arranged in spikelet (distichous in Isolepis levynsiana)
Involucral bracts glume-like or leaf-like, from shorter than inflorescence to twice as long as it (to 1.5 cm long); spikelets 2–8 mm long
Involucral bracts culm-like, usually at least 4 times as long as inflorescence (to 25 cm long); spikelets 5–15 mm long
Glumes distichously arranged in spikelet (spirally arranged in Cyperus hamulosus, and then plant curry-scented)
Glumes spirally arranged in spikelet (distichous in Isolepis levynsiana); plant not curry-scented
Nuts transversely wrinkled and/or stout perennials
Nuts variously marked but never transversely wrinkled; small annuals or perennials
Rhizomatous perennial with thick and woody rhizome to 1 cm diam.  (Ficinia nodosa) or small tufted annual (Ficinia marginata); nut with a small, sometimes deciduous, basal lobed disk
Tufted annual or perennials, rhizome absent or filiform; nut without a basal disk
Female flowers enclosed in sac-like utricle
Flowers not enclosed in a utricle

Inflorescence a sessile ovoid or hemispherical head of pseudospikelets; female flowers apparently terminal, always only 1 per pseudospikelet (floral unit) with 10–25 stamen-subtending or sterile glumes below it
Inflorescence not as above; female or bisexual flowers lateral and axillary, one to many in a spikelet, often with a few stamen-subtending or sterile glumes above or below them
A hypogynous disk or 1 or 2 hyaline scales or 2–6 hypogynous bristles or scales present at base of nut (not always falling with nut)
Hypogynous bristles, scales and disk absent
Nut more or less enclosed in 2, or occasionally 1, hyaline scales; small annual with inflorescence of 1–4 ovoid clustered heads with numerous spikelets
Nut without hyaline scales; inflorescence various
[link through]
Style simple or 2-fid
Style 3- to 8-fid
Style-base not differentiated or enlarged or persistent; leaves with a membranous ligule; dry forests or woodlands of the far east
Style-base differentiated, enlarged, and persistent; leaves without a ligule; damp sites in the north-east only
[link through]
[link through]
Hypogynous disk present at base of nut
Hypogynous bristles or scales present at base of nut
[link through]
Upper internodes of rachilla prominently zigzagged
Upper internodes of rachilla straight
Hypogynous scales 3, flat, antrorsely plumose below, apex with 1 long bristle-like lobe, often with 2 smaller flat lateral lobes; both aerial and basal spikelets produced
Hypogynous scales or bristles 2–6; if scales, flat but not plumose or 3-lobed; spikelets aerial only
[link through]
Style-base persistent, often enlarged in fruit
Style-base deciduous
Inflorescence head-like, globose, terminal on long, wiry culm, and plants forming large tussocks or inflorescence head-like, hemispherical to obovoid and plants < 40 cm high
Inflorescence panicle-like, umbel-like, or spike-like
Large tussock-forming perennial; culms often > 1 m long; ligule membranous and ciliate; inflorescence globose; hypogynous bristles 2 or 3, filiform, antrorsely scabrous
Small tufted perennial; culms 14–40 cm high; ligule absent; inflorescence condensed-compound and appearing head-like, hemispherical to obovoid; hypogynous bristles 6, plumose
[link through]
[link through]
Hypogynous bristles 6, as long as, or longer than the nut and falling with it
Hypogynous bristles 2–4, much shorter than the nut, not falling with it
[link through]
Inflorescence condensed-compound and appearing head-like, hemispherical to obovoid; hypygynous bristles flat and not inflated, plumose
Inflorescence panicle-like, umbel-like, spike-like or consisting of a single spikelet; hypygynous bristles or scales inflated (in Lepidosperma) or flat and not inflated, glabrous, scabrous or ciliate
[link through]
Glumes spirally arranged in the spikelet; hypogynous scales inflated
Glumes ± distichously arranged in the spikelet; hypogynous scales flat, not thickened
Hypogynous scales persistent on rachilla after nut falls; leaf with pseudopetiole; alpine, wet heaths and bogs
Hypogynous scales falling with the nut; leaf without pseudopetiole; lowland heaths and woodlands
[link through]
Style simple or 2-fid
Style 3- to 8-fid
Style-base enlarged, persistent
Style-base not enlarged or persistent
[link through]
Upper internodes of rachilla zigzagged
Upper internodes of rachilla straight
Annual; inflorescence of 1–4 ovoid clustered heads with numerous spikelets
Perennials; inflorescence panicle-like, spike-like, or occasionally reduced to a few clustered spikelets
[link through]
Leaves reduced to blades no more than 1 cm long
Leaves with well-developed blades to 1 m long or more
Persistent style-base not separated from body of nut by a constriction
Persistent style-base separated from body of nut by a constriction
Leaves without a ligule
Leaves with a ligule
[link through]
Leaves 2-ranked, flattened laterally (strictly isobilaterally)
Leaves 3-ranked, flattened dorsiventrally
Nut borne on inconspicuous hypogynous disk (disk may stay on rachilla rather than fall with nut)
Nut not borne on a hypogynous disk
[link through]
Spikelets disarticulating as a unit from axis at maturity
Spikelets persistent, nuts falling separately from glumes at maturity
Leaves with a ligule
Leaves without a ligule
[link through]
